title: Hearts open investigation after Rangers striker Alfredo Morelos was allegedly racially abused
text:
Hearts have launched a probe into allegations that Rangers forward Alfredo Morelos was subject to racial abuse during the SPL clash between the two sides.

The game, which finished 1-1, saw Morelos netting an equaliser for Steven Gerrard's men, and he celebrated his goal in front of the home fans.

And now Hearts have released a statement on the reported incident, vowing to hand out an 'indefinite ban' to any supporter found guilty of racial abuse.

Alfredo Morelos places his finger to his lips as he celebrates his goal in front of the Hearts fans

'The club is aware of an incident of alleged racism and is currently investigating it,' the statement read.

'It goes without saying that Heart of Midlothian Football Club utterly condemns any form of racism and any individuals found guilty of such an offence will face an indefinite ban from Tynecastle Park.'

Ryotaro Meshino had given Hearts an early lead before Morelos' first-half leveller, but the SPL title hopefuls were not able to find a winner at Tynecastle.

Hearts said it 'utterly condemns' all forms of racism and will ban any offending supporters

Tyrone Mings was the target of racist abuse during England's game against Bulgaria last week

The alleged abuse in the game comes amid a torrent of reported racism from fans in recent weeks, with England's game against Bulgaria a high-profile game that was nearly abandoned following monkey noises and Nazi salutes from the stands.

The likes of Raheem Sterling and Tyrone Mings were subject to the abuse as the Three Lions ran out 6-0 winners in Sofia, with Uefa launching their own investigation into the horrific scenes.

Meanwhile, Haringey Borough v Yeovil in the FA Cup qualifying rounds had to be abandoned after Haringey players walked off the pitch following reports of racist abuse from the crowd.
